p: Acute and recurrent herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) infections remain an important problem due to the emergence of acyclovir resistant virus. As a result of that, the search for novel antiviral bioactive compounds from plants has intensified in recent years. The antiviral activity of methanol, hexane, and chloroform extract of M. vulgare showed antiviral activity with selectivity indices of 3.11, 2.8, and 1.28, respectively. This study revealed that the hexane fraction disrupts the early steps of cyclic replication, including HSV-1 attachment, in a dose-dependent manner [ 99].
